title: Discarding and Recovering
intent: Improve flow and resilience by intentionally removing elements when they are no longer useful, while keeping the ability to restore them if needed.

triz_principle.name: Discarding and Recovering
triz_principle.definition: Make parts of an object or system disappear after completing their function, or restore them when required.

problem_understanding.core_contradiction: We want stability and traceability, but keeping everything forever creates clutter, cost, and rigidity.
problem_understanding.why_this_hurts: Unused artifacts, data, rules, and processes accumulate and slowly strangle system evolution.
typical_signals: dead configuration nobody dares to remove
fear of cleanup because rollback is unclear

solution_logic.core_idea: Design explicit lifecycle: create → use → discard → optionally recover.
solution_logic.key_rule: Nothing is permanent unless it proves long-term value.
solution_logic.how_it_resolves_the_contradiction: The system stays lean while retaining the ability to recover knowledge or functionality when needed.

consulting: sunset plans for initiatives and policies
enterprise_sap: temporary MDG rules removed after migration phases
cleanup of unused workflows and replication settings

anti_patterns: cleanup driven by crisis instead of policy

use_when: change is blocked by legacy clutter

diagnostic_questions: Which elements no longer deliver value?
What could safely expire by default?
How can recovery be made cheap and reliable?

example.before: Old validation rules and workflows remain active long after their original purpose is gone.
example.after: Rules expire automatically and can be restored from versioned history if needed.
